bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 7, 1954

div1.p: Hench writes Nogueira about his upcoming visit to Cuba, thanks him for the decoration he recently received, and enlists his aid in persuading Presno to consent to the microfilming of Finlay's daybooks.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, January 7, 1954
div1.opener:
January 7, 1954
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I suspect that you may have heard that a month ago, quite unbeknownst to me,
the Cuban Government voted me another decoration. I am extremely grateful
to my Cuban friends and their very kind and sympathetic interest in me. I
knew nothing about this matter but it was published in the New York Times
and friends told me of it. Probably you not only knew something about it
but may very well have had much to do with it. I am certainly grateful to
you and my other friends.

It is probable also that you had heard that Mrs. Louise Flood Smith of F.I.M.
has asked me to come down during their “Nutrition Week” and I have promised
to do so. Mary and I will fly down, arriving in Havana late Tuesday night,
January 26. We can only stay a very few days and will probably fly back on
Sunday, January 31. Our friends at the Finca San Jose have invited us to
stay with them and we have gladly accepted.

I must see you while we are there for two reasons: First of all, on a
matter of interest to Doctor Soper. I understand that you and I are
among those who are advising him regarding selected translations of the
works of Finlay. I am glad to help in this matter and he wants me to talk
to you.

Secondly, I am anxious to receive your further help in the matter of micro-
filming the Finlay diaries as you and I have discussed before. I enclose a
copy of a letter that I have sent to Doctor Presno. Surgeon General Arm-
strong is very anxious to have a microfilm copy and has written me a very
nice note asking me to be his agent in the matter. General Armstrong thinks
that the microfilming could be done much cheaper at the Surgeon General's
Library than anywhere else; on the other hand, if Doctor Presno feels that
it should be done in Havana, so be it. In any event, I want Doctor Presno
to understand that both General Armstrong and I want to have a copy made
at our expense (if it is not too costly) to present to the Academy of
Sciences Library. I am hoping that a negative can be made from which four
positive copies can be made. I am not sure how they do it but in any
event, the copies I hope to have made are one for the Surgeon General's
Library, one for Doctor Presno and the Academy of Sciences in Havana, one
for myself and, as a taken of my sincere appreciation of your great help,
a fourth copy for you.

In as much as I have mentioned your name in my letter to Doctor Presno,
would it be appropriate or possible for you to contact him fairly soon
so that perhaps by the time of my arrival he can have made up his mind
what to do about the matter. If he will permit me this time to bring
the books along to Washington, I will do so. If he wants the micro-
film made in Havana, perhaps they could actually be done by the time of
my arrival and I could bring the two back home; the copy for myself of
course to be permanently filed in the Library of the Mayo Clinic.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
